comments: FNCE 100 provides an introduction to the theory, the methods, and the concerns of corporate finance. The concepts developed in FNCE 100 form the foundation for all elective finance courses. The main topics include: the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; security market efficiency; optimal capital structure, and dividend policy decisions. FNCE 100 was called “the most applicable and useful course I have taken at Penn” and Professor Kiku was highly praised. Virtually every student described her as an “excellent instructor,” “very patient,” and perhaps most importantly, “very clear in explaining the material.” Most people felt that the pace of the class was good, though a few felt it was too slow at times. A few students mentioned that she could be “a little harsh when people answer incorrectly.” Others would have liked more office hours. The criticisms of the course were mostly directed at the course format. The grading system was “extremely tough.” A few students suggested “getting rid of the participation grade.” Quizzes “cover a lot of material,” and students expressed great dislike of “subtracting points for wrong answers on multiple choice.” One student complained that “the real exams are far more difficult and it’s misleading.” Finally, while one of the lectures reviews relevant statistics materials, a few students did not feel that was sufficient to refresh them.

FNCE 100 provides an introduction to the theory, the methods, and the concerns of corporate finance. The concepts developed in FNCE 100 form the foundation for all elective finance courses. The main topics include: the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; security market efficiency; optimal capital structure, and dividend policy decisions. FNCE 100 was called “the most applicable and useful course I have taken at Penn” and Professor Kiku was highly praised. Virtually every student described her as an “excellent instructor,” “very patient,” and perhaps most importantly, “very clear in explaining the material.” Most people felt that the pace of the class was good, though a few felt it was too slow at times. A few students mentioned that she could be “a little harsh when people answer incorrectly.” Others would have liked more office hours. The criticisms of the course were mostly directed at the course format. The grading system was “extremely tough.” A few students suggested “getting rid of the participation grade.” Quizzes “cover a lot of material,” and students expressed great dislike of “subtracting points for wrong answers on multiple choice.” One student complained that “the real exams are far more difficult and it’s misleading.” Finally, while one of the lectures reviews relevant statistics materials, a few students did not feel that was sufficient to refresh them.
